Dear CAROL BANKS:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
February 21, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with the child protection law
• (1) An agency shall comply with the child
protection law, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to
722.638.
Two of two new employee files reviewed did not have documentation the agency
was in compliance with the child protection law as they did not complete the DCWL
Children’s Protective Services history review as required.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (5) An agency shall inform the foster parent of and
discuss the agency's policy and procedures
regarding concurrent planning.
Two of three foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the foster
parents were informed of, and agrees to follow, agency policies and procedures.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the
2

department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
Two of three foster home files reviewed did not have documentation the licensing
recommendation was made to the department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration of the foster home license.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (a) The date the information was received.
Two of two special investigations reviewed did not have a report completed within
15 days of the conclusion of the investigation.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
• (b) Child’s date of birth.
• (c) Available known information about the
child’s health.
• (d) Any known history of abuse or neglect
of the child.
• (e) All known emotional and psychological
factors relating to the care of the child.
• (f) All known behaviors of the child.
• (g) Circumstances necessitating placement
or replacement of the child.
• (h) Any other known information to enable
the foster parent to provide a stable, safe,
and healthy environment for the foster child
and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the
foster home as provided in federal law.
• (i) Name of the assigned social service
worker.
3

• (j) Authorization to provide routine and
emergency medical care.
One of three foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-j of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframe outlined within the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
Two of three foster care files reviewed (3 of 9 service plans) did not have the
Updated Service Plan completed timely.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outline in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP)-within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP)-within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP)-within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, stepdown
from a residential or hospital setting, return from
4

AWOLP, or request for change in foster home/relative
placements.
Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS 1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.
Two of three foster care files reviewed contained FTM's without the DHS 1105 or
the DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement agency
foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
Two of three foster care files reviewed (4 of 9 service plans) did not contain all of the
required signatures on the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/youth adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must be
documented in the electronic case management record.
5

All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child’s current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is temporary
court ward.
• Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
• At reunification. Subsequent medical passports
are not required after reunification.
• Non-offending parent, subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and accepted
for treatment or services prior to or at the first
schedule appointment while the foster care case
is open, regardless of placement. Subsequent
medical passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults:
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth
aged 16 and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults
aged 18 and older).
• YAVFC youth/young adult.
Two of three foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and required
signatures.

• All employment references obtained need to be dated.
• Letter that accompanied foster home licensing renewal application needs
to be uploaded in CWLM.
• Cover letter that lists agency policies/procedures reviewed with foster
parent and signed can be uploaded instead of each individual policy/procedure.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request consultation.
6

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
renewal inspection completed on 2/13/2023 with a corrective action plan approved
on 2/23/2023. During the review, the agency had three violations: R 400.12212
(2)(b) Personnel records (verification of education), R 400.12212 (2)(h) Personnel
records (Central Registry clearance) and R 400.12312 (4) Foster parent training
(current First Aid/CPR). No violations were noted as repeat violations in the
current inspection. During this period under review the agency noted that overall
compliance was impacted by staffing issues.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting requirements during
this review period. The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the agency had more
MDHHS placements over this past year than in previous years. As a result, the
agency experienced a learning curve regarding timely data entry. In addition, the
agency has had some difficulty filling vacancies. They are small and not able to
match the wages that larger agencies can. The agency has also faced some
challenges related to staying on top of updating processes and procedures due to
many staff being responsible for multiple duties.
The CA indicated the agency HR checklist was updated as a result of last year’s
audit and reports that as being a positive change. The agency has experienced
some staffing changes and the Chief Administrator expressed confidence that
several areas will improve over the next review period.
Financial Overview
Financial records were reviewed and there were no concerns identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff face-to-face at the agency. Staff reported
supervisors meet with them regularly and coworkers are available to assist as
needed. Staff reported feeling supported by the agency and had no concerns.
7

Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely
including CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
